Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone, in terms of maximum sustained winds, on record to impact Australia.

Total_Summary_Insured_Damage.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: According to the Northern Territory Insurance Office, structural damage from Cyclone Monica amounted to A$5 million (US$4.4 million).

Total_Insured_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: According to the Northern Territory Insurance Office, structural damage from Cyclone Monica amounted to A$5 million (US$4.4 million).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: Insured damages to the national parks amounted to A$1.6 million (US$766,000).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Displaceme.Displacement_with_annotation: At one point, Monica was forecast to pass directly over Goulburn Island. In response, officials evacuated the island's 337 residents to shelters set up in Pine Creek.

Location_with_Annotation.Papua New Guinea: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica originated from an area of low pressure that formed early on 16 April 2006 off the coast of Papua New Guinea.
Location_with_Annotation.Queensland: Upon being declared as Tropical Cyclone Monica on 17 April, the Bureau of Meteorology issued a gale warning for areas along the eastern coast of Far North Queensland and for northern New South Wales.
Location_with_Annotation.Northern Territory: On 24 April 2006, Monica made landfall about 35 km (22 mi) west of Maningrida, at the same intensity.
Location_with_Annotation.Lockhart River: During the afternoon of 19 April, the storm made landfall roughly 40 km (25 mi) south-southeast of the Lockhart River with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph) 10-minute sustained).
Location_with_Annotation.Mossman: A storm surge of 1.23 m (4.0 ft) was recorded in Mossman and waves were recorded up to 4.24 m (13.9 ft) in Weipa.
Location_with_Annotation.Weipa: A storm surge of 1.23 m (4.0 ft) was recorded in Mossman and waves were recorded up to 4.24 m (13.9 ft) in Weipa.
Location_with_Annotation.Torres Strait: Three Torres Strait Islanders were rescued after 22 days drifting at sea in the wake of the cyclone passing through the Torres Strait, north of mainland Queensland.
Location_with_Annotation.Maningrida: Wind gusts up to 148 km/h (92 mph) felled power lines in Maningrida;
Location_with_Annotation.Jabiru: 12 homes sustained damage from fallen trees in Jabiru;
Location_with_Annotation.Gunbalanya: extensive damage was reported in Gunbalanya (formerly known as Oenpelli).
Location_with_Annotation.Darwin: Several flights in and out of Darwin were also cancelled, as was the Darwin Anzac Day march.
Location_with_Annotation.Goulburn Island: In response, officials evacuated the island's 337 residents to shelters set up in Pine Creek.
Location_with_Annotation.Wessel Islands: The Wessel Islands, located off the coast of the region, suffered significant damage from the storm.
Location_with_Annotation.Junction Bay: Around the region where Monica made landfall, evidence of a 5–6 m (16–20 ft) storm surge was present in Junction Bay.
Location_with_Annotation.Goomadeer River: The Goomadeer River catchment, which flows into Junction Bay, was entirely denuded.
Location_with_Annotation.Magela Creek: Farther southwest, the Magela Creek catchment in Kakadu National Park suffered a direct hit from the weakening cyclone.
Location_with_Annotation.Ngarradj sub-catchment: Gusts up to 135 km/h (84 mph) impacted the Ngarradj sub-catchment, destroying 42 percent of the tree canopy cover.
Location_with_Annotation.Gulungul Creek: Additional studies at the Gulungul Creek and the Alligator Rivers region revealed that suspended sediment values in flowing water had temporarily increased in the wake of Monica.
Location_with_Annotation.Alligator Rivers region: Additional studies at the Gulungul Creek and the Alligator Rivers region revealed that suspended sediment values in flowing water had temporarily increased in the wake of Monica.
Location_with_Annotation.Arnhem forests: In a study of the Arnhem forests which were devastated by the cyclone, environmentalists reported that it would take over 100 years for the forest to recover.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: No injuries were reported to have occurred during the storm's existence and losses were estimated to be A$6.6 million (US$5.1 million).

Total_Economic_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: No injuries were reported to have occurred during the storm's existence and losses were estimated to be A$6.6 million (US$5.1 million).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: Insured damages to the national parks amounted to A$1.6 million (US$766,000).
According to the Northern Territory Insurance Office, structural damage from Cyclone Monica amounted to A$5 million (US$4.4 million).

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: The full-force of Monica's estimated 360 km/h (220 mph) wind gusts were felt in the unpopulated tropical savanna regions of northern Australia.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: The highest 24-hour rainfall from the storm was recorded near Darwin at 340 mm (13 in). A storm total for the same area was recorded at 383 mm (15.1 in), surpassing the rainfall record for the entire month of April set in 1953.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Flash flooding was reported throughout the Adelaide River basin as up to 261 mm (10.3 in) of rain fell in a 24-hour span.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Building_D.Building_Damage_with_annotation: Officials reported about 15 percent of the structures along the Lockhart River sustained minor damage.
Wind gusts up to 148 km/h (92 mph) felled power lines in Maningrida.
12 homes sustained damage from fallen trees in Jabiru.
Extensive damage was reported in Gunbalanya (formerly known as Oenpelli).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Affected.Affected_with_annotation: An estimated 1,000 people were planned to be evacuated in Far North Queensland before officials shut down major highways in the area.
An aborigine community of 700, located around the mouth of the Lockhart River, were in the direct path of the storm.
In response, officials evacuated the island's 337 residents to shelters set up in Pine Creek.
Roughly 1,000 people also lost phone service in the region.
